alert.note: Alert for Chaffee; Saguache (Colorado) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued August 04 at 9:03PM MDT until August 04 at 10:45PM MDT by NWS Pueblo
info.description: ...FLASH FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 1045 PM MDT THIS EVENING FOR SOUTHEASTERN CHAFFEE AND NORTH CENTRAL SAGUACHE COUNTIES... At 903 PM MDT, local law enforcement reported flash flooding and a debris flow across the warned area. Flash flooding is already occurring. HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Earlier thunderstorms that produced flash flooding. SOURCE...Law enforcement reported flash flooding and a debris flow from the Poncha Pass area toward and east of Poncha Springs. IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses. Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Poncha Pass and Poncha Springs. This includes the following high risk locations... Highway 285 south of Poncha Springs to Poncha Pass. This includes the following streams and drainages... Pass Creek, Brewery Creek, Middle Creek, Beaver Creek, Marshall Creek, Starvation Creek, East Middle Creek, Bear Creek, Silver Creek, Arkansas River, San Luis Creek, Kerber Creek, Poncha Creek, Droz Creek, Tank Seven Creek, Indian Creek, Stumpy Creek, Harry Creek, Redman Creek, Little Cochetopa Creek, Green Creek and South Arkansas River. FLASH FLOOD...OBSERVED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CONSIDERABLE
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Move away from recently burned areas. Life-threatening flooding of creeks, roads and normally dry arroyos is likely. The heavy rains will likely trigger rockslides, mudslides and debris flows in steep terrain, especially in and around these areas. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. It is important to know where you are relative to streams, rivers, or creeks which can become killers in heavy rains. Campers and hikers should avoid streams or creeks.
